name: Ruyi Jingu Bang
shortDescription: Sun Wukong's magical staff that can change size at will, weighing 17,550 pounds
fullDescription: The Ruyi Jingu Bang (Â¶ÇÊÑèÈáëÁÆçÊ£í, 'As-You-Will Golden Hooped Rod') is the legendary weapon of Sun Wukong, the Monkey King. Originally a pillar used by the Dragon King of the Eastern Sea to measure ocean depths, this divine iron staff can shrink to the size of a needle or grow to cosmic proportions. Weighing 13,500 jin (17,550 lbs), it is inscribed with gold bands and responds to its master's commands. The staff is nearly indestructible and serves as both weapon and tool throughout the Journey to the West.

mythologyContexts.usage: Primary weapon of Sun Wukong, the Monkey King, used to fight demons, challenge heaven, and protect Tang Sanzang on the journey to retrieve Buddhist scriptures from India

rituals.name: Claiming the Staff
rituals.description: Sun Wukong visited the Dragon Palace and claimed the staff as his weapon after it responded to his will, shrinking to fit his hand

rituals.name: Havoc in Heaven
rituals.description: Used to battle the celestial armies when Sun Wukong rebelled against the Jade Emperor

rituals.name: Journey to the West
rituals.description: Served as the primary weapon to defeat 81 tribulations during the pilgrimage to retrieve Buddhist scriptures

textReferences.context: Sun Wukong obtains the staff from the Dragon King's palace
The staff is used during the Havoc in Heaven rebellion

mythologyContexts.symbolism: The Ruyi Jingu Bang represents adaptability, divine power channeled through individual will, and the bridge between earthly and celestial realms. Its ability to change size symbolizes the flexibility needed to overcome any obstacle. The staff's origin as a tool of measurement transformed into a weapon represents the potential for transformation and the claiming of one's destiny.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: The staff is one of the most iconic objects in Chinese literature and has become synonymous with Sun Wukong himself. It appears in countless adaptations, films, and cultural works. The concept of a weapon that adapts to its wielder's needs has influenced martial arts philosophy and storytelling across Asia.
